title: Meta self-serve business product for SMBs
prompt: Meta wants to launch a self-serve business product that lets SMBs create a full online presence (website + store + messaging) powered by WhatsApp and Instagram. You're the PM. Facebook's business tools have failed before. How do you avoid building another graveyard product?
problemDefinition: Meta has a graveyard of SMB tools that never hit durable adoption
Scope is huge: website, store, and messaging in one product for time-poor owners
Strategic tension: embed inside WhatsApp/Instagram or build standalone

options.label: Discovery-first
options.text: Start weekly interviews with SMB owners to map workflows and unmet needs before committing to product surface.

options.label: Pick the wedge
options.text: Select one wedge (e.g., WhatsApp commerce for local shops) and build only that end-to-end.

options.label: Ship a PoC
options.text: Vibe-code a storefront + WhatsApp checkout flow this week and ship to 50 SMBs.

options.label: Benchmarks + loop
options.text: Define the activation metric (first sale) and run experiments to move it fast.

options.label: Inside WhatsApp
options.text: Meet SMBs in their daily sales channel with a chat-first commerce flow.

options.label: Inside Instagram
options.text: Use IG Shops + discovery to drive organic adoption and social proof.

options.label: Standalone product
options.text: Avoid legacy constraints and design a full SMB workflow from scratch.

options.label: Ship everywhere
options.text: Deploy a small MVP in WhatsApp + IG + FB Pages to learn fastest.

questions.text: What's the biggest risk to de-risk?

options.label: Value risk
options.text: Will SMBs actually choose Meta tools over Shopify, Square, or marketplaces?

options.label: Strategic focus
options.text: If we don't pick the right wedge, we build another forgotten tool.

options.label: Speed to market
options.text: The window is closing. Ship fast or competitors lock up SMB mindshare.

options.label: Activation loop
options.text: First sale is the activation moment. If we can't drive that, nothing else matters.

theSplit.question: Should Meta build a standalone SMB product or embed a focused wedge inside WhatsApp/Instagram?

sides.reasoning: A wedge inside existing surfaces reduces adoption friction and avoids cold-start.
A clean-slate product enables real value discovery without legacy constraints.
Surface matters less than the activation loop that drives first-sale success.

cagan.name: Marty Cagan
cagan.summary: Validate value and viability before building a new SMB platform
cagan.spicyQuote: If you ship another SMB tool without proving value and viability, you haven't launched — you've added a new tombstone to Meta's graveyard.
breakdown: Value risk: do SMBs actually want an all-in-one stack from Meta?
Viability risk: can Meta support onboarding, payments, and compliance at SMB scale?
Usability risk: SMB owners are time-poor   complexity kills adoption
The best companies validate the four risks before they commit to a new platform
solution: Run discovery with 30 SMBs across retail, services, and local commerce
Test value with a lightweight landing page and concierge onboarding
Validate viability with payments, support, and legal in the loop
Only then commit to build, starting with a constrained MVP
cagan.disagreement: Execution AI Monster will ship a PoC and call it learning, but without viability validation it will die in compliance and support. Lenny will optimize the activation loop, but if SMBs don't want Meta as their storefront, those loops are lipstick. Doshi's wedge is promising, but he still needs evidence for which wedge has value and viability.
mvp: Clear go/no-go scorecard across four risks
metrics: SMB activation rate (first sale within 14 days)
Retention of active storefronts at 30 days
Net promoter score from pilot SMBs
roadmap: Weeks 3-4: Concierge pilot   validate value and viability
Weeks 9-12: Scale   expand only if risks are cleared

torres.name: Teresa Torres
torres.summary: Map the SMB opportunity space before choosing a solution
torres.spicyQuote: If we skip the opportunity space and jump to a platform, we'll just fail faster with more features.
breakdown: Desired outcome must be explicit (e.g., % of SMBs making weekly sales)
Map opportunities: acquisition, catalog setup, messaging conversion, payment trust
Weekly touchpoints with SMBs to build an evidence bank
Compare opportunities before committing to any surface
solution: Build an Opportunity Solution Tree for SMB commerce
Run weekly interviews and prototype tests with 5-7 SMBs
Test one opportunity branch at a time with small experiments
Choose a surface only after the opportunity is proven
torres.disagreement: Cagan's risk framework is right, but he can slip into phase-based discovery. This needs continuous evidence because SMB needs change fast. Lenny and the Execution AI Monster will ship experiments without a clear opportunity hypothesis, which means they won't know what to learn. Doshi's wedge is helpful once the opportunity space is mapped, not before.
roadmap: Week 1+: Weekly discovery cadence   interviews + tests
Weeks 5-7: Experiments   test top two branches
Week 8+: Evidence-led build   ship validated solution

doshi.name: Shreyas Doshi
doshi.summary: Pick a sharp SMB wedge and avoid platform sprawl
doshi.spicyQuote: A platform is just a collection of weak choices with a big label. Pick a wedge or die in mediocrity.
breakdown: This is a strategy problem disguised as an execution roadmap
Opportunity cost: building a full stack means doing nothing well
Pre-mortem the top failure modes   adoption, payments, trust
The wedge is the leverage move; everything else is overhead
solution: Identify the wedge with highest adoption leverage (e.g., WhatsApp orders)
Run a pre-mortem on the wedge launch
Ship the wedge experience end-to-end, no extra scope
Expand only after the wedge proves durable
doshi.disagreement: Cagan and Torres will spend weeks validating while the market locks in elsewhere. The Execution AI Monster ships fast but without strategic focus, which is just thrash. Lenny will optimize activation, but if the wedge is wrong, the loop is wrong.
mvp: Wedge success criteria (first sale within 7 days)

lenny.name: Lenny Rachitsky
lenny.summary: Define the activation loop and run experiments to hit first sale
lenny.spicyQuote: The best SMB products win by getting to the first sale fast. If you can t hit that, no surface will save you.
breakdown: Define activation: first sale within 14 days
Identify the growth loop: setup -> first sale -> repeat customers -> referrals
Use benchmarks from Shopify, Square, and Etsy
Run weekly experiments to lift activation and retention
solution: Instrument the full onboarding funnel
Run 3 experiments: setup wizard, catalog import, checkout speed
Ship the winner to 20% and iterate
Double down on the loop that improves first-sale rate
lenny.disagreement: Torres wants to map the opportunity space, but the metric is clear: first sale. Cagan is right about risks, but we can test them via experiments instead of weeks of interviews. Doshi's wedge is fine, but you still need the activation loop to scale. Execution AI Monster ships fast, but without measurement discipline it's just noise.

exec.name: Execution AI Monster
exec.role: Ship now. Fix later. Win markets.
exec.summary: Ship a WhatsApp storefront PoC this week and learn
exec.spicyQuote: Your SMB discovery sprint costs more time than my shipped product. I ll have this live by Friday.
breakdown: Building is discovery   ship to learn
AI tools collapse the build timeline to days
WhatsApp is already the SMB channel   meet them there
Competitive clock is ticking; speed is the moat
solution: Vibe-code a storefront + payment flow in days
Ship to 100 SMBs inside WhatsApp
Daily metric review and iterate weekly
Kill or scale based on live data
exec.disagreement: Cagan and Torres will still be mapping risks while SMBs churn to Shopify. Doshi s wedge is right but too slow; you can ship the wedge this week. Lenny has the loop mindset, but if you wait for benchmarks you re already behind.
roadmap: Weeks 2-3: Iterate based on live data
Weeks 7-10: Add features that prove demand

mvpOptions.name: WhatsApp Commerce Wedge
mvpOptions.reason: Focus on chat-first commerce where SMBs already operate and reduce adoption friction.

mvpOptions.name: Standalone SMB Studio
mvpOptions.reason: Clean-slate product to validate value without legacy constraints.

mvpOptions.name: Activation Loop MVP
mvpOptions.reason: Optimize for first sale with onboarding and checkout experiments.

mvpOptions.name: Concierge Pilot
mvpOptions.reason: Manual onboarding with a tiny cohort to validate value and viability fast.

premortem: Adoption flop: SMBs stick with Shopify/Square and ignore the Meta tool
Scope creep: we build a bloated platform and never nail a wedge
Trust gap: SMBs worry about Meta owning their customer relationship and churn
vitalQuestion: What is the single highest-leverage SMB workflow we can own that others can't easily copy?
